title: Shraddhatraya Vibhaga Yoga
subtitle: The Yoga of the Threefold Faith
summary: In this chapter, Lord Krishna classifies faith, food, sacrifice, austerity, and charity into three categories—sattvic (pure), rajasic (passionate), and tamasic (ignorant). He explains how each type influences human behavior and spiritual growth, emphasizing that true spiritual practices are performed with faith, devotion, and without selfish motives.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः | तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः ||
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca | ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ | teṣāṁ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what is the state of those who disregard scriptural injunctions but still worship with faith? Is it sattva, rajas, or tamas?
verses.explanation: Arjuna inquires about the nature of people who perform rituals with faith but ignore scriptural guidelines, questioning whether their faith is pure, passionate, or ignorant.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा | सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु ||
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca | tri-vidhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṁ sā svabhāva-jā | sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṁ śṛṇu ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: The faith of embodied beings is of three kinds—sattvic, rajasic, and tamasic—according to their innate nature. Hear now about these.
verses.explanation: Krishna introduces the threefold division of faith, rooted in the natural tendencies (guna) of individuals.

verses.sanskrit: सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत | श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः ||
verses.transliteration: sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata | śraddhā-mayo'yaṁ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
verses.translation: O Bharata, the faith of each person aligns with their inner nature. A person is made of faith; whatever one’s faith is, that indeed one becomes.
verses.explanation: Krishna explains that faith reflects one's dominant guna (sattva, rajas, or tamas) and shapes their identity and actions.

verses.sanskrit: यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान्यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः | प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः ||
verses.transliteration: yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṁsi rājasāḥ | pretān bhūta-gaṇāṁś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ ||
verses.translation: Sattvic people worship the gods; rajasic people worship demigods and demons; tamasic people worship ghosts and spirits.
verses.explanation: The object of worship varies based on one's guna—elevated beings for the sattvic, power-oriented entities for the rajasic, and dark forces for the tamasic.

verses.sanskrit: अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः | दम्भाहंकारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः || कर्शयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः | मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान् ||
verses.transliteration: aśāstra-vihitaṁ ghoraṁ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ | dambhāhaṅkāra-saṁyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ || karśayantaḥ śarīra-sthaṁ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ | māṁ caivāntaḥ-śarīra-sthaṁ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān ||
verses.translation: Those who practice severe austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, motivated by hypocrisy, ego, lust, and attachment, who torment their bodily organs and Me dwelling within—know them to be of demonic resolve.
verses.explanation: Krishna condemns extreme penances performed without scriptural guidance, driven by ego and selfish desires.

verses.sanskrit: आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः | यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं शृणु ||
verses.transliteration: āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ | yajñas tapas tathā dānaṁ teṣāṁ bhedam imaṁ śṛṇu ||
verses.translation: Even food, sacrifice, austerity, and charity are of three kinds. Hear now the distinctions between them.
verses.explanation: Krishna extends the threefold classification to diet, rituals, discipline, and charity.

verses.sanskrit: आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः | रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः ||
verses.transliteration: āyuḥ-sattva-balārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ | rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvika-priyāḥ ||
verses.translation: Foods dear to the sattvic promote longevity, vitality, strength, health, happiness, and joy. They are juicy, wholesome, and pleasing to the heart.
verses.explanation: Sattvic foods nourish the body and mind, enhancing purity and well-being.

verses.sanskrit: कट्वम्ललवणात्युष्णतीक्ष्णरूक्षविदाहिनः | आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःखशोकामयप्रदाः ||
verses.transliteration: kaṭv-amla-lavaṇāty-uṣṇa-tīkṣṇa-rūkṣa-vidāhinaḥ | āhārā rājasasyeṣṭā duḥkha-śokāmaya-pradāḥ ||
verses.translation: Foods that are bitter, sour, salty, excessively hot, pungent, dry, and burning are favored by the rajasic, causing pain, grief, and disease.
verses.explanation: Rajasic foods stimulate passion but lead to physical and mental distress.

verses.sanskrit: यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत् | उच्छिष्टमपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम् ||
verses.transliteration: yāta-yāmaṁ gata-rasaṁ pūti paryuṣitaṁ ca yat | ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṁ bhojanaṁ tāmasa-priyam ||
verses.translation: Food that is stale, tasteless, putrid, rotten, and impure is dear to the tamasic.
verses.explanation: Tamasic foods promote ignorance, lethargy, and delusion.

verses.sanskrit: अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते | यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः ||
verses.transliteration: aphalākāṅkṣibhir yajño vidhi-dṛṣṭo ya ijyate | yaṣṭavyam eveti manaḥ samādhāya sa sāttvikaḥ ||
verses.translation: The sattvic sacrifice is performed according to scriptural injunctions, without desire for reward, with a focused mind.
verses.explanation: Sattvic rituals are selfless acts of devotion, free from material expectations.

verses.sanskrit: अभिसन्धाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत् | इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम् ||
verses.transliteration: abhisandhāya tu phalaṁ dambhārtham api caiva yat | ijyate bharata-śreṣṭha taṁ yajñaṁ viddhi rājasam ||
verses.translation: O best of the Bharatas, the rajasic sacrifice is performed for show or with expectation of reward.
verses.explanation: Rajasic sacrifices are motivated by ego, pride, or material gain.

verses.sanskrit: विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम् | श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते ||
verses.transliteration: vidhi-hīnam asṛṣṭānnaṁ mantra-hīnam adakṣiṇam | śraddhā-virahitaṁ yajñaṁ tāmasaṁ paricakṣate ||
verses.translation: The tamasic sacrifice disregards scriptural rules, lacks proper food offerings, mantras, charity, and faith.
verses.explanation: Tamasic rituals are hollow, performed without devotion or adherence to tradition.

verses.sanskrit: देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम् | ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते ||
verses.transliteration: deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjanaṁ śaucam ārjavam | brahmacaryam ahiṁsā ca śārīraṁ tapa ucyate ||
verses.translation: Austerity of the body includes worship of the gods, sages, teachers, and the wise; purity, honesty, celibacy, and non-violence.
verses.explanation: Physical austerity involves righteous conduct and reverence for higher principles.

verses.sanskrit: अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत् | स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते ||
verses.transliteration: anudvega-karaṁ vākyaṁ satyaṁ priya-hitaṁ ca yat | svādhyāyābhyasanaṁ caiva vāṅ-mayaṁ tapa ucyate ||
verses.translation: Austerity of speech consists of truthful, pleasant, beneficial words, and regular recitation of sacred texts.
verses.explanation: Verbal austerity promotes harmony through kind and truthful communication.

verses.sanskrit: मनःप्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः | भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते ||
verses.transliteration: manaḥ-prasādaḥ saumyatvaṁ maunam ātma-vinigrahaḥ | bhāva-saṁśuddhir ity etat tapo mānasam ucyate ||
verses.translation: Mental austerity includes serenity, gentleness, silence, self-control, and purity of thought.
verses.explanation: Inner discipline cultivates peace, self-restraint, and clarity of mind.

verses.sanskrit: श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः | अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते ||
verses.transliteration: śraddhayā parayā taptaṁ tapas tat tri-vidhaṁ naraiḥ | aphalākāṅkṣibhir yuktaiḥ sāttvikaṁ paricakṣate ||
verses.translation: Threefold austerity (physical, verbal, mental) practiced with supreme faith by those seeking no reward is sattvic.
verses.explanation: Selfless discipline, performed with devotion, elevates consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत् | क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम् ||
verses.transliteration: satkāra-māna-pūjārthaṁ tapo dambhena caiva yat | kriyate tad iha proktaṁ rājasaṁ calam adhruvam ||
verses.translation: Austerity performed for show, honor, or praise is rajasic—unsteady and impermanent.
verses.explanation: Discipline driven by ego or social recognition is fleeting and fruitless.

verses.sanskrit: मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः | परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ||
verses.transliteration: mūḍha-grāheṇātmano yat pīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ | parasyotsādanārthaṁ vā tat tāmasam udāhṛtam ||
verses.translation: Austerity performed with foolish stubbornness, involving self-torture or harm to others, is tamasic.
verses.explanation: Ignorant penance, whether self-destructive or violent, leads to darkness.

verses.sanskrit: दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे | देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम् ||
verses.transliteration: dātavyam iti yad dānaṁ dīyate 'nupakāriṇe | deśe kāle ca pātre ca tad dānaṁ sāttvikaṁ smṛtam ||
verses.translation: Charity given out of duty, without expectation of return, at the right time and place to a worthy person, is sattvic.
verses.explanation: Selfless giving, guided by wisdom and humility, is divine.

verses.sanskrit: यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः | दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम् ||
verses.transliteration: yat tu pratyupakārārthaṁ phalam uddiśya vā punaḥ | dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṁ tad dānaṁ rājasaṁ smṛtam ||
verses.translation: But charity given reluctantly, with expectation of return or reward, is rajasic.
verses.explanation: Giving motivated by selfish desires binds one to material outcomes.

verses.sanskrit: अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते | असत्कृतमवज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ||
verses.transliteration: adeśa-kāle yad dānam apātrebhyaś ca dīyate | asatkṛtam avajñātaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛtam ||
verses.translation: Charity offered at an improper time or place, to unworthy recipients, without respect or with contempt, is tamasic.
verses.explanation: Ignorant charity, devoid of discernment or reverence, is harmful.

verses.sanskrit: ओं तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः | ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा ||
verses.transliteration: oṁ tat sad iti nirdeśo brahmaṇas tri-vidhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇās tena vedāś ca yajñāś ca vihitāḥ purā ||
verses.translation: “Om Tat Sat” is the threefold designation of Brahman (the Absolute). By this were ordained the Brahmanas, the Vedas, and sacrifices of old.
verses.explanation: Krishna reveals the sacred syllables “Om Tat Sat” as the eternal foundation of spiritual truth.

verses.sanskrit: तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः | प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम् ||
verses.transliteration: tasmād om ity udāhṛtya yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ | pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṁ brahma-vādinām ||
verses.translation: Therefore, acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity are always begun with the utterance of “Om” by those following the Vedas.
verses.explanation: Sacred rituals should commence with “Om” to invoke divine consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: तदित्यनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः | दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभिः ||
verses.transliteration: tad ity anabhisandhāya phalaṁ yajña-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ | dāna-kriyāś ca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ ||
verses.translation: Without seeking rewards, those desiring liberation perform sacrifices, austerities, and acts of charity with the utterance of “Tat” (That).
verses.explanation: The syllable “Tat” signifies selfless action dedicated to the Supreme.

verses.sanskrit: सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते | प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते || यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते | कर्म चैव तदर्थीयं सदित्येवाभिधीयते ||
verses.transliteration: sad-bhāve sādhu-bhāve ca sad ity etat prayujyate | praśaste karmaṇi tathā sac-chabdaḥ pārtha yujyate || yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ sad iti cocyate | karma caiva tad-arthīyaṁ sad ity evābhidhīyate ||
verses.translation: The word “Sat” is used to denote goodness and virtue, O Partha. The term “Sat” is also used for auspicious actions. Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity, and charity is called “Sat,” and actions for the sake of the Supreme are also termed “Sat.”
verses.explanation: “Sat” represents truth, virtue, and devotion to the Divine in all endeavors.

verses.sanskrit: अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत् | असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह ||
verses.transliteration: aśraddhayā hutaṁ dattaṁ tapas taptaṁ kṛtaṁ ca yat | asad ity ucyate pārtha na ca tat pretya no iha ||
verses.translation: Whatever is done as sacrifice, charity, or austerity without faith is called “asat” (unreal), O Partha. It is worthless here and hereafter.
verses.explanation: Actions devoid of faith—no matter how grand—bear no spiritual fruit.
